metadata.title: Note from the editors: Don’t stop thinking about tomorrow
metadata.author: Eurosurveillance editorial team
affiliations: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), Stockholm, Sweden Correspondence: Eurosurveillance editorial team (eurosurveillance@ecdc.europa.eu)
metadata.abstract: One memorable event was the worldwide movement of young people for the climate. Even if not directly related to infectious disease prevention and control, it reminded us of our collective obligation to the upcoming generations. Disease prevention is about improving future health outcomes. Continuous vigilance and surveillance are necessary elements in ensuring the best possible protection of the heath of the population as a whole. Pathogens continue to evolve in their ability to cause human disease. This was demonstrated by the recent detection of pneumonia cases of unknown origin in Wuhan, China since mid-December, for which an unknown, novel corona virus has been preliminarily determined as the cause [1,2]. An example of how pathogens are able to escape tools and technologies developed to control and stop their spread is antimicrobial resistance (AMR). AMR has been a worldwide concern for some time already and has featured prominently in Eurosurveillance. In 2019, we covered various aspects of AMR such as the emergence of multidrug-resistant Neisseria gonorrhoeae related to international travel [3], an outbreak of extensively drug-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae in a German hospital [4], and the surveillance of antimicrobial consumption and prescribing for example in Belgium, Israel and Switzerland [5-7]. Another aspect driving spread and severity of communicable diseases is human behaviour. The continued spread of measles in Europe over the past decade has been facilitated by insufficient vaccine coverage in specific population groups or regions. Over the past year, vaccine hesitancy and mandatory vaccination were covered in several Eurosurveillance articles [8] as were interventions to improve confidence in vaccines, for example, motivational interviews conducted with parents of newborns on maternity wards in Canada resulted in lower hesitancy and greater intention to vaccinate [9].

data_availability: supplementary material referenced in the article can be found in the online version.
introduction: One memorable event was the worldwide movement of young people for the climate. Even if not directly related to infectious disease prevention and control, it reminded us of our collective obligation to the upcoming generations. Disease prevention is about improving future health outcomes. Continuous vigilance and surveillance are necessary elements in ensuring the best possible protection of the heath of the population as a whole. Pathogens continue to evolve in their ability to cause human disease. This was demonstrated by the recent detection of pneumonia cases of unknown origin in Wuhan, China since mid-December, for which an unknown, novel corona virus has been preliminarily determined as the cause [1,2]. An example of how pathogens are able to escape tools and technologies developed to control and stop their spread is antimicrobial resistance (AMR). AMR has been a worldwide concern for some time already and has featured prominently in Eurosurveillance. In 2019, we covered various aspects of AMR such as the emergence of multidrug-resistant Neisseria gonorrhoeae related to international travel [3], an outbreak of extensively drug-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae in a German hospital [4], and the surveillance of antimicrobial consumption and prescribing for example in Belgium, Israel and Switzerland [5-7]. Another aspect driving spread and severity of communicable diseases is human behaviour. The continued spread of measles in Europe over the past decade has been facilitated by insufficient vaccine coverage in specific population groups or regions. Over the past year, vaccine hesitancy and mandatory vaccination were covered in several Eurosurveillance articles [8] as were interventions to improve confidence in vaccines, for example, motivational interviews conducted with parents of newborns on maternity wards in Canada resulted in lower hesitancy and greater intention to vaccinate [9].

As usual, food- and waterborne diseases, HIV/AIDS and blood-borne diseases, emerging and vector-borne diseases, influenza and other respiratory diseases were the subject of several articles in the categories, ‘Outbreak reports’ and ‘Surveillance articles’. These two article types have different structures and collectively replaced the former category ‘Surveillance and outbreak reports’ at the beginning of 2019. The associated new instructions for authors have led to greater consistency and completeness of information in submissions in these article categories.

References: 1. World Health Organization (WHO). Pneumonia of unknown cause – China. Geneva: WHO; 2019. Available from: https://www.who.int/csr/don/05january-2020-pneumonia-of-unkown-cause-china/ en/

2. World Health Organization (WHO). WHO Statement Regarding Cluster of Pneumonia Cases in Wuhan, China. Geneva: WHO; 2019. Available from: https://www.who.int/china/news/ detail/09-01-2020-who-statement-regarding-cluster-ofpneumonia-cases-in-wuhan-china

3. Eurosurveillance. Collection: Emerging multidrug-resistant Neisseria gonorrhoeae related to international travel. Stockholm: ECDC. [Accessed 8 Jan 2020]. Available from: https://eurosurveillance.org/content/travel-associatedmultidrug-resistant-resistant-neisseria-gonorrhoeae

4. Haller S, Kramer R, Becker K, Bohnert JA, Eckmanns T, Hans JB, et al Extensively drug-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae ST307 outbreak, north-eastern Germany, June to October 2019. Euro Surveill. 2019;24(50):1900734. https://doi.org/10.2807/15607917.ES.2019.24.50.1900734 PMID: 31847948

5. Vandael E, Magerman K, Coenen S, Goossens H, Catry B. participants.context: We also published articles on less frequently encountered topics such as a skin rash outbreak traced to a portable floating tank [11] and urban brown rats as the possible source of multidrug-resistant Enterobacteriaceae and meticillin-resistant Staphylococcus [12]. In 2019, we published 220 articles (65 rapid communications, 155 regular articles and 21 other items such as editorials, letters and meeting reports). The 2019 acceptance rate of 25% was similar to previous years

keywords: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control
summary: One memorable event was the worldwide movement of young people for the climate. Even if not directly related to infectious disease prevention and control, it reminded them of the collective obligation to the upcoming generations.
Disease prevention is about improving future health outcomes.
An example of how pathogens are able to escape tools and technologies developed to control and stop their spread is antimicrobial resistance (AMR).

In 2019, the authors covered various aspects of AMR such as the emergence of multidrug-resistant Neisseria gonorrhoeae related to international travel [3], an outbreak of extensively drug-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae in a German hospital [4], and the surveillance of antimicrobial consumption and prescribing for example in Belgium, Israel and Switzerland [5-7].
A special issue published in January 2019 illustrated How advanced diagnostics support public health policy development [10].
The authors will continue to welcome contributions from around the globe that are relevant for public health in Europe in the year ahead.
The authors' rapid communications on ongoing or emerging threats were published within 2 to 3 weeks of submission, creating awareness and providing evidence to support rapid public health action.

The 2019 seminar about Pointof-care testing (POCT) and its impact on surveillance of communicable diseases and public health was well received and the authors look forward to publishing a respective special issue sometime in early spring.

Other 2019 activities by the Eurosurveillance editors comprised several workshops on publication ethics, tools to increase transparency in scholarly communications, and on how authors can improve their chances of getting published.

All this could not have been achieved without the involvement of so many amazing supporters and constructive critics: the editorial board members, colleagues at the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), public health experts and scientists in the field of infectious diseases and other disciplines in Europe and elsewhere who respond when the authors ask for assistance and who remain unnamed here.

Together with the contributors and supporters, the authors are constantly working to maintain Eurosurveillance as a useful means to provide sound and trustworthy evidence for communicable disease prevention and control in the future.

In 2020, the authors will discuss with the editorial board the strategy and goals for the years 2021 to 2027; the authors envisage to further advance to follow new developments and meet the demands of the diverse audience to the best of the abilities in the time to come.

The authors hope that many of you will respond and help them shape the future of the journal, so that Eurosurveillance continues to be interesting for readers, attractive for authors and useful for strategic and day-to-day public health decision-making.

Introduction: One memorable event was the worldwide movement of young people for the climate. Even if not directly related to infectious disease prevention and control, it reminded them of the collective obligation to the upcoming generations.
Disease prevention is about improving future health outcomes.
An example of how pathogens are able to escape tools and technologies developed to control and stop their spread is antimicrobial resistance (AMR).
Results: In 2019, the authors covered various aspects of AMR such as the emergence of multidrug-resistant Neisseria gonorrhoeae related to international travel [3], an outbreak of extensively drug-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae in a German hospital [4], and the surveillance of antimicrobial consumption and prescribing for example in Belgium, Israel and Switzerland [5-7].
A special issue published in January 2019 illustrated How advanced diagnostics support public health policy development [10].
The authors will continue to welcome contributions from around the globe that are relevant for public health in Europe in the year ahead.
The authors' rapid communications on ongoing or emerging threats were published within 2 to 3 weeks of submission, creating awareness and providing evidence to support rapid public health action.

The 2019 seminar about Pointof-care testing (POCT) and its impact on surveillance of communicable diseases and public health was well received and the authors look forward to publishing a respective special issue sometime in early spring.

Other 2019 activities by the Eurosurveillance editors comprised several workshops on publication ethics, tools to increase transparency in scholarly communications, and on how authors can improve their chances of getting published.

All this could not have been achieved without the involvement of so many amazing supporters and constructive critics: the editorial board members, colleagues at the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), public health experts and scientists in the field of infectious diseases and other disciplines in Europe and elsewhere who respond when the authors ask for assistance and who remain unnamed here.
Conclusion: Together with the contributors and supporters, the authors are constantly working to maintain Eurosurveillance as a useful means to provide sound and trustworthy evidence for communicable disease prevention and control in the future.

In 2020, the authors will discuss with the editorial board the strategy and goals for the years 2021 to 2027; the authors envisage to further advance to follow new developments and meet the demands of the diverse audience to the best of the abilities in the time to come.

The authors hope that many of you will respond and help them shape the future of the journal, so that Eurosurveillance continues to be interesting for readers, attractive for authors and useful for strategic and day-to-day public health decision-making.

key_statements: One memorable event was the worldwide movement of young people for the climate
Disease prevention is about improving future health outcomes

Pathogens continue to evolve in their ability to cause human disease. This was demonstrated by the recent detection of pneumonia cases of unknown origin in Wuhan, China since mid-December, for which an unknown, novel corona virus has been preliminarily determined as the cause [1,2]
antimicrobial resistance has been a worldwide concern for some time already and has featured prominently in Eurosurveillance

In 2019, we covered various aspects of antimicrobial resistance such as the emergence of multidrug-resistant Neisseria gonorrhoeae related to international travel [3], an outbreak of extensively drug-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae in a German hospital [4], and the surveillance of antimicrobial consumption and prescribing for example in Belgium, Israel and Switzerland [5-7]

Vaccine hesitancy and mandatory vaccination were covered in several Eurosurveillance articles [8] as were interventions to improve confidence in vaccines, for example, motivational interviews conducted with parents of newborns on maternity wards in Canada resulted in lower hesitancy and greater intention to vaccinate [9]
We will continue to welcome contributions from around the globe that are relevant for public health in Europe in the year ahead
top_statements: One memorable event was the worldwide movement of young people for the climate
Disease prevention is about improving future health outcomes

Pathogens continue to evolve in their ability to cause human disease. This was demonstrated by the recent detection of pneumonia cases of unknown origin in Wuhan, China since mid-December, for which an unknown, novel corona virus has been preliminarily determined as the cause [1,2]

In 2019, we covered various aspects of antimicrobial resistance such as the emergence of multidrug-resistant Neisseria gonorrhoeae related to international travel [3], an outbreak of extensively drug-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae in a German hospital [4], and the surveillance of antimicrobial consumption and prescribing for example in Belgium, Israel and Switzerland [5-7]

Vaccine hesitancy and mandatory vaccination were covered in several Eurosurveillance articles [8] as were interventions to improve confidence in vaccines, for example, motivational interviews conducted with parents of newborns on maternity wards in Canada resulted in lower hesitancy and greater intention to vaccinate [9]
headline: Vaccine hesitancy and mandatory vaccination were covered in several Eurosurveillance articles as were interventions to improve confidence in vaccines, for example, motivational interviews conducted with parents of newborns on maternity wards in Canada resulted in lower hesitancy and greater intention to vaccinate
